title: Who was Marieke Vervoort and what illness did the Paralympian have?
text:
Marieke Vervoort after winning the silver in the Women’s 400m in Rio (Picture: Al Tielemans for OIS/IOC/Getty)

Marieke Vervoort, a Belgian Paralympian, has ended her own life through euthanasia at the age of 40.

Marieke, who won gold and silver in the London 2012 Paralympics, announced two years ago she planned to end her life as she struggled with pain from a degenerative disease.

A statement from her home city of Diest said Vervoort ‘responded to her choice on Tuesday evening’.

What illness did Marieke Vervoort have?

Vervoort was a Paralympian who not only triumphed at the 2012 Games in wheelchair racing, but also won a silver and bronze medal at the 2016 Rio Paralympics.

Through her successes, she also suffered an incurable spinal condition which caused constant pain, seizures and paralysis in her legs.

The athlete spoke of her struggles with the condition extensively in recent years, describing her sleepless nights and the toll it was taking.

Vervoort’s home city confirmed her death (Picture: Leo Correa/AP/Getty)

She said: ‘It’s too hard for my body. Each training I’m suffering because of pain. Every race I train hard. Training and riding and doing competition are medicine for me. I push so hard – to push literally all my fear and everything away.’

In 2008, Vervoort signed documentation which would one day allow a doctor to end her life.

She said: ‘I’m really scared, but those [euthanasia] papers give me a lot of peace of mind because I know when it’s enough for me, I have those papers.

‘If I didn’t have those papers, I think I’d have done suicide already. I think there will be fewer suicides when every country has the law of euthanasia. I hope everybody sees that this is not murder, but it makes people live longer.’

Vervoort lived with an incurable degenerative disease (Picture: Gareth Copley/Getty)

Is euthanasia legal?

Euthanasia – the act of deliberately ending a person’s life to relieve them from suffering – is legal in Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Canada and Colombia.

It is not the same as assisted suicide – deliberately assisting or encouraging another person to kill themselves – however the latter is legal in the Netherlands, Switzerland, Germany and a number of US states.

Both euthanasia and assisted suicide are illegal under English law with euthanasia considered manslaughter or murder, depending on circumstances, and assisted suicide punishable by up to 14 years’ imprisonment.
description: Marieke Vervoort has ended her own life 11 years after signing documentation allowing doctors to do so through euthanasia.
